did.unittitle: New York Shipbuilding Corporation business papers

bioghist.p: The New York Shipbuilding Corporation (or New York Ship for short) was founded in 1899 and opened its first shipyard in 1900. Located in Camden, New Jersey on the east shore of the Delaware River, New York Ship built more than 500 vessels for the U.S. Navy, the United States Merchant Marine, the United States Coast Guard, and other maritime concerns.

scopecontent.p: Photos and negatives of ships built by the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, contracts #1-542 (not complete). Images include ships during construction, completed ships, launches, a few interior and deck views. There are also photographs of the yard facilities, docks, shops, and equipment; executive staff; participants in the apprentice program; open houses; awards ceremonies; and aerial views of the yard taken in 1960. There are a number of photograph albums of keel laying and launching events (1958-1965). Other materials in the collection include: a small number of general body plans for ships; several plans for shipboard systems; plans and drawings of NYSC yards and buildings; scrapbook of newspaper clippings, 1955-1956, with articles on NYSC and on Louis E Wolfson (board chairman of NYSC); newspaper clippings about a 1935 shipbuilders' strike. There are a small number of records records related to specific contract numbers. These materials include job orders, blueprint logbooks, and specifications. Printed materials include: printed contract and specification books, for contract #5-387 (not complete); newsletters (York Ship News, 1919-1921 and Shipways, 1958-1959); histories of NYSC; brochures on ships; launch invitations; and engineering manuals. Other items include facilities inventory, 1964; printed agreement between NYSC and the AFL-CIO, 1966; printed rules of employment, 1966; list of contracts; and a claim by NYSC for an adjustment to the contact with the US Bureau of Ships for USS Kitty Hawk, 1961, and other assorted materials. The collection also includes a small number of materials related to Sun Shipbuilding, including copies of the newsletter Our Yard and plans for a hydro-test stand. And published volumes on the [naval engineering] firm of Merritt-Chapman and Scott.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
